In exercise of powers conferred by Section SA of the Aircraft Act, 1934 (XXII of 1934),
read with rule 3 (b) of the Aircraft (Security) Rules, 2011, Director General, Bureau of Civil
Aviation Security (DG, BCAS), for the purpose of safety of passengers, crew, ground personnel
and the general public in all matters related to safeguarding against acts of unlawful interference
‘with civil aviation, directs that the Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul (MRO) Security Programme
which has", been prepared to comply with the provisions laid down in ICAO Doc 8973 and
security related provisions of NCASP and NQCP, shall be implemented by all MRO agencies
connected with civil aviation security in India. The model template is available on the BCAS
restricted site.

2. In terms of the said provisions, every MRO agency shall, with the approval of DG, BCAS,
make and comply with the MRO Security Programme as per said template and any amendment to
such programme shall be made only after the approval of DG, BCAS. No MRO agency shall be
allowed to commence its operations from an airport / off airport in India unless its MRO Security
Programme has been approved by the DG, BCAS.

3. The MRO Security Programme shall be valid for a period of five (05) years and it shall be
updated in accordance with the security directions issued by the DG, BCAS from time to time.
Before expiry, a revised MRO Security Programme in respect of the concemed MRO agency shall
be submitted at least three months in advance for further approval process.

4, Any violation of this AVSEC Order shall attract penalty under Section 11 A of the Aircraft
Act 1934,

NCASP and NQCP provides for the development, implementation and
maintenance of security programme for MRO. Aviation Security Manual (Doc
8973) of ICAO also states the requirement of security programme for MRO
(Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul). A security programme constitutes a
blueprint for developing a civil aviation security system. It reflects the clearly
defined, unambiguous responsibilities assigned to each entities.

Doc 8973 clearly highlights that such facilities should be located at the
airside and landside boundary of the airport, but staff members should not
be allowed to circulate on the aprons used by commercial aircraft. As with
any other facility with access to the airside, maintenance facilities should
develop their own security programme consistent with the NCASP.

In addition to the usual threats posed by staff with access to the
airside, or persons accessing the airside via maintenance facilities, there are
specific threats to be considered for maintenance operations, such as
sabotage of aircraft via maintenance operations, dangerous items placed in
hidden parts of an aircraft for future use by perpetrators, and deliberate
actions to create malfunctions of aircraft equipment.

1. Policy

1.1 MRO security programme should be adopted as corporate policy and
should describe the objectives with respect to security. It calls for the
establishment of a security department and chief security officer whose
responsibilities involve achieving the cited objectives. The programme
should set out the related responsibilities of employees, and handling
agents and other contractors. The security measures described should be
clearly defined and easily understood by those who need to implement
them.

1.1.1, MRO security programmes should have a_ security
classification in accordance with national guidelines.

1.1.2, In developing MRO security programme, risk should be
analysed in depth and the nature and level of threat facing the operator
should be assessed. National and airport security requirements,
programme implementation timelines, staffing and financial limitations,
and enhanced security requirements during times of increased threat,
should also be considered. The applicability of the aircraft operator
security programme should also be appraised, since it may apply only
to a particular airport or group of airports, a particular service or a
specific State.

1.2 Policy Management

1.2.1 To ensure that policies do not become obsolete, ZZ
will implement a regular review process of them. That process should
include some form of update mechanism so that changes in organization’s
operating environment can be quickly translated into security policy.
There is, therefore, a definite need to constantly review security measures
and modify the design in consonance with the current threat.

2 Primary Objective:

‘The primary objective of MRO security programme is to ensure the safety and
Security of aircraft by preventing acts of unlawful interference. To that end,
RRND curiy programme shall:

a) meet or exceed the requirements of the NCASP.

b) provide for standardized security measures and for clear security

directives for Engineers, Accountable Manager/Maintenance Manager,

Foreign experts (authorized by DGCA), Trainees (apprentices), other

employees, handling agents and contracted staff;

provide for additional security measures in times of increased security

threat; and

d) set performance standards, achievable through initial and recurrent
training and monitored in accordance with recordkeeping requirements
set out in the NCASP.

3 Legal Authority:

3.1. The Aircraft (Security) Rules, 2011 empowers the Director General,
Bureau of Civil Aviation Security as the appropriate authority responsible
for the development, implementation and maintenance of Security
Programmes. The security programme shall be approved by the appropriate
authority.

3.3. DGCA will allow operation only after the security programme is
approved by BCAS. No MRO shall be allowed to operate in India unless the
security programme is approved.
